Subjective: The patient has had a spot on their neck for about two weeks.
The spot started as a small wound after shaving.
The spot became thicker after an insect bite.
The spot became redder after an insect bite.
The patient has not had any similar skin spots in the past.
There is a family history of skin complaints caused by the sun.
The patient's request for help is to find out what the spot is.
The patient wants to know what treatment is available for the spot.
Objective: There is a raised spot on the neck.
The spot is approximately 0.5 cm in size.
The spot is pinkish-red in colour.
The spot has a slightly redder centre.
The spot does not have a scab.
There are no palpable lymph nodes in the neck.
Assessment: There is a suspicion of a pyogenic granuloma on the neck.
There is a suspicion of an atypical mole on the neck.
Plan: A photograph of the spot has been taken.
The photograph of the spot has been sent to dermatology via e-consultation for assessment.
It has been agreed that the general practitioner will contact the patient by telephone on Friday to discuss the results.
Possible treatment with cryotherapy using liquid nitrogen was discussed.
Possible treatment with surgical excision under local anaesthetic was discussed.
In the event of surgical excision, tissue examination was discussed.
It was agreed that if there was no immediate telephone contact on Friday, a voicemail message with advice would be left.
